Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Planning And Land Management in Tropical Ecosystem; Complexities of land-use and hydrology coupling in the Panama Canal Watershed
Award.AbstractNarration:
The sustainability of the Panama Canal is intricately connected with land-use. The Canal was created by damming the Chagres River, creating Lake Gatun. Each ship passing through the Canal requires release of water from Lake Gatun, so reliable operation of the Canal requires reliable runoff from the Panama Canal watershed. This is particularly true during the extended dry season, when rainfall essentially stops. Furthermore, floods during the wet season can cause closure of the Canal. The Panama Canal is undergoing a significant expansion to allow passage by larger ships. Canal operations are a vital US interest. Approximately 20 percent of trade between the U.S. and Asia passes through the Panama Canal representing five percent of global trade, and the Canal enables a large number of US jobs. However, the Canal expansion will require more water despite the new high efficiency locks. Land management in the Panama Canal Watershed influences how much and when water drains into Lake Gatun and the Canal. This project will map the flow of land use policy incentives from authorities like Panama Canal Authority, through landholder response, to changes in land use and cover, to the effects of flow into the Canal. This will help predict human and hydrological responses to policy and identify the least cost approach to providing hydrologic ecosystem services. This project includes international components conducted in the country of Panama and is funded in part with funds from NSF ISE funds.


This project will evaluate the hydrology of the Panama Canal region as a response to land use policy incentives from authorities like Panama Canal Authority, through landholder response, to changes in land use and cover, to the effects of flow into the Canal. Preliminary results suggest that land management decisions alter paths available for water to flow from the land into the Canal. These "preferential flow paths" are created by soil cracking in the dry season, and by biological factors such as plants, animals, and microbes. Conversion of grazing lands to forest seems to increase the amount of water flowing through the soil. This may increase groundwater recharge, an important source of dry season river flows. Forest land cover may reduce flooding in the wet season. The project will collect watershed-scale hydrologic data in different land uses and covers, and analyze those data to quantify the roles of deforestation and grazing on hydrologic behavior. Researchers will measure the factors affecting participation in an existing land-use incentive system to implement land management systems that may improve the flow regime to the Canal. The findings from the physical and socio-economic studies will be merged into a hydro-socio-economic model to predict future water resources availability in the Panama Canal watershed, driven by different land-management and climate scenarios.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Panama Canal Watershed is extremely important to the U.S. economy. Seaborne commerce between the U.S. and other countries represents the dominant use of the Panama Canal. Since starting in 2013, this research project has met its goals to (1) advance hydrological understanding in the steep humid tropics, (2) understand factors affecting land owner decisions on participation in paid land management schemes, and (3) combine this into an integrated assessment of the potential of long-term payments for hydrological ecosystem services in the Panama Canal Watershed.

Advance Hydrologic Understanding

Our project took advantage of existing research infrastructure provided by the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute, Agua Salud Project, allowing us to examine the effects of land cover and land use on hydrological response in the watershed that provides all the river flow that powers the Panama Canal. We collected hydrometeorological, runoff, and geochemical data. We used electrical resistivity tomography geophysical techniques and simulated rainfall to make observations of different behaviors in sub-watersheds that were typical of the different land-uses and physiography of the Panama Canal Watershed. These data and observations allowed us to develop, test, and refine physically-based models of hydrological response that gave us predictive understanding of the effects of land cover on flow path and runoff generation mechanism. These models and the understanding they represent allowed us to extrapolate our results to the scale of the entire Panama Canal Watershed, and test the efficacy of different land management scenarios in terms of changes in water availability for operation of the Panama Canal and hydropower production, changes in risk of peak flows, sediment deliveries and resultant dredging requirements. The hydrological research benefited from the engagement of non-hydrologists in terms of new ways of looking at and communicating data.

Understand Landowner's Decision Process Regarding Payments Schemes

We developed theory and empirical understanding of the performance of payments schemes for hydrological services. Theoretical results suggest the importance of missing or weak financial services markets, such as the ease of obtaining a loan, as a barrier to private individuals providing ecosystem services to improve dry-season water flows. Empirical research was based on an in-person surveys of land-use decision makers in the Panama Canal Watershed covering approximately one fifth of the non-forested area in the canal watershed. We found that most, but not all, land-use decision makers were willing to alter lands to provide hydrological services for a mix of monetary and in-kind incentives. Land-use decision makers generally preferred subsidized loans to direct payment streams (holding other factors constant), which supports our theory and suggests that barriers in the financial sector partially lead to under provision of ecosystem services. Indeed, some respondents opted for loans with positive interest rates, expressing a willingness to pay to provide the ecosystem service because it is a productive agroforestry practice. Insurance and technological assistance influenced the probably of program adoption. The survey data set provided a rich picture of agriculture in the Panama Canal Watershed. These data fostered production of other research products relevant to social science and economics. The social science research benefited from insights provided by natural scientists in terms of the important questions to ask.

Evaluate Long-Term Water Resources Benefits to Land Management Payments

Through our predictive understanding of land cover effects on hydrological response and our understanding of the costs associated with different levels of landholder involvement in different portions of the Panama Canal Watershed, we synthesized our results into a hydro-socio-economic model that provided an indication of the costs and benefits associated with different land management scenarios. Results indicated that converting pastures to agroforestry and forest land-uses provides a benefit to canal operations because lands covered by older forests absorb rainfall during the wet season and release it during the dry season. However, in most places in the watershed the costs to land-use decision makers of restoring this 'forest sponge' exceed the benefits to canal operation. However in some low benefit areas the costs are even lower, suggesting a small payments program could be feasible and efficient. Another challenge to landscape change providing hydrological benefits, is that the 'forest sponge' cannot operate at the same scale as traditional infrastructure projects, despite the fact that an efficient payments program to restore the forest sponge has a similar benefit-cost ratio as engineering works. Areas that receive the greatest rainfall are generally forested. Losing those forests, which provide significant forest sponge effect, could be very costly. We have shared our results with the Panama Canal Authority and have a publication explaining these synthesis results under consideration by the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
